info.game_comments:
Ben Tritle game 1.
First game in which runners-up are awarded cash prizes ($2,000 for 2nd place and $1,000 for 3rd place).

(2, 1).clue: Parnell Hall & Nero Blanc write mysteries you may have come across & can't put down as they include these puzzles

(3, 1).clue: One of the games on "The Price Is Right" is this find-the-ball con game

(4, 1).clue: A Florida law prohibits catching a shark, removing these & not saving the carcass for consumption

(5, 1).clue: This "golden bear", won the 1973 PGA Championship by 4 strokes & was the year's top money-winner

(6, 1).clue: Some like it ___ under the collar

(1, 2).clue: Barbra Streisand made her Broadway debut in "I Can Get It For You" this way

(2, 2).clue: As Sue Grafton had the alphabet locked up, Janet Evanovich is using these for her Stephanie Plum titles

(3, 2).clue: In this type of "scheme" you send money to the 5 people who joined the scheme ahead of you & add your name to the list

(4, 2).clue: The largest fish on earth, this shark feeds mainly on microscopic plankton

(5, 2).clue: In Super Bowl VII, Don Shula coached this team to a 14-7 victory over the Redskins, completing a 17-0 season

(1, 3).clue: To reduce prices, or to illegally lower the mileage on your odometer

(2, 3).clue: Aida Marcuse translated this children's classic into Spanish as "Huevos Verdes Con Jamon"

(3, 3).clue: In this bird "drop", a wad of money is found & the con man will split it with you if you put up some of your own money

(4, 3).clue: Usually under 5 feet in length, the bonnethead is one of the smaller species of this shark

(5, 3).clue: In 1973's Final Four this school beat Memphis State 87-66, to easily win its 7th straight NCAA basketball title

(1, 4).clue: Sedimentary term for the very lowest price, it's also the lowest level you can hit financially

(2, 4).clue: "Suzanne's Diary for Nicholas" is a 2001 change of pace for this suspense writer known for his Alex Cross books

(3, 4).clue: Hans van Meegeren had a "brush" with success as one of the most famous ones of these of the 20th century

(4, 4).clue: This organ of the basking shark may yield 200 gallons of oil

(5, 4).clue: Notre Dame won college football's nat'l title after a         24-23 Sugar Bowl win over this school's Crimson Tide

(1, 5).clue: Faux-medical term for a car buyer's reaction to an unexpectedly high price

(2, 5).clue: 2001's "Black House" is this pair's sequel to "The Talisman"

(3, 5).clue: Patrick Penker got picked up in Texas after passing  bad checks bearing the name of this law firm from The Three Stooges

(4, 5).clue: With a name from the Maori, this powerful mackerel shark is also called the blue pointer or bonito

(5, 5).clue: This Bay Area team had to come from behind & win games 6 & 7 to win the 1973 World Series against the Mets

(2, 1).clue: Examples of these collegiate organizations include Lambda, Chi Alpha & Sigma Chi

(3, 1).clue: 1993: "What would you do if you were stuck in one place & every day was exactly the same?"

(4, 1).clue: The earliest known bio of this "father of medicine" was written around 100 A.D. by Soranus, a Greek doctor

(5, 1).clue: It's the only U.S. state named for a president

(6, 1).clue: The procedure involving paying your hotel bill & leaving

(2, 2).clue: (Sarah wears a red football helmet as Alex reads the clue.) The emblem seen here is worn by the athletic teams of this college established in 1880

(4, 2).clue: This Russian physiologist wrote the 1927 work "Conditioned Reflexes"

(5, 2).clue: In 1991 Leningrad reverted to this name, after its founder's patron saint

(6, 2).clue: A coupon that guarantees an offer that cannot be fulfilled at the present time

(2, 3).clue: To symbolize healing following the Civil War, Georgetown University adopted these as its school colors

(3, 3).clue: 1980: "A cinderella story outta nowhere former greenskeeper and now about to become the Masters champion"

(4, 3).clue: This author wrote "The Andromeda Strain" while pursuing a medical degree at Harvard

(5, 3).clue: Explorer John Speke named this large African lake after the queen of England

(6, 3).clue: In 1960 & 1962 he twisted his way into the No. 1 spot on the charts with "The Twist"

(2, 4).clue: John Elway graduated from this college that bears the name of a railroad-building California governor

(4, 4).clue: In 1955 this British physician published his autobiography, "Four-Minute Mile"

(5, 4).clue: You'd be wise to remember that Guadalcanal is part of this island chain named for a biblical person

(6, 4).clue: It's where police inspect vehicles at a border crossing

(2, 5).clue: Yes sir, William Tecumseh Sherman's alma mater was this service academy

(3, 5).clue: '82: "I... appreciate your doing this but it is just for the money, isn't it?  It's not just so you can wear these... outfits?"

(4, 5).clue: This professor of pediatrics at the Univ. of Arkansas medical school became head of the Arkansas dept. of health in 1987

(5, 5).clue: This explorer gave his name to a sea & a huge Antarctic ice shelf

(6, 5).clue: It's found at the finish line

(0, 0).clue: This 100-member unit still wears uniforms originally designed by Michelangelo in the 16th century
